toc_entry.title: The Snootiest Neighborhood In Texas
toc_entry.description: The residents of San antonio’s King William Historic District saved their neighborhood from bums, bulldozers, and bogus bay windows. Now, if they can only save it from themselves.

toc_entry.title: Hate Thy Neighbor
toc_entry.description: A look at Houston’s Meyerland, Dallas’ Munger Place, El Paso’s Sunset Heights, and austin’s Hyde Park shows that few fights get the blood boiling like a good fight with a neighbor.

toc_entry.title: Root, Root, Root For the Home Team
toc_entry.description: All there is to know about Texas baseball, including the best ballpark, the best team ever, why Yogi Berra thinks Houston is like New Jersey, and much, much more.
toc_entry.byline: by Joe Nick Patoski and John Morthland

toc_entry.title: Unionbusters
toc_entry.description: Hank Milam was a businessman with $20,000 in equipment and a firm faith in the rules of the game. He took on the union that had ruled the Houston docks for fifty years and beat it on its own turf.

toc_entry.title: The Fire Ant
toc_entry.subtitle: Texas Primer
toc_entry.description: Baby calves, children, even the agriculture commissioner: no one is safe from this tiny demon.

toc_entry.title: Grasslands
toc_entry.description: In the early journals of pioneers who described the prairie surrounding their new homesteads, the ocean was the most common metaphor —swells of grass set rippling by the wind.

toc_entry.title: Eating Up the Miles
toc_entry.subtitle: Food
toc_entry.description: Our gadabout gourmet travels three thousand miles to answer the question, Where should you eat on your next Texas highway trip?.

toc_entry.title: Slow-Motion Dilemma
toc_entry.subtitle: Movies
toc_entry.description: Violets are Blue is swimming in heavy conflict; Wise Guys is mostly slob humor; absolute Beginners is an absolute mess; at Close Range is a violent ambush.

toc_entry.title: Nine Days Of Solitude
toc_entry.subtitle: Books
toc_entry.description: The Story of a Shipwrecked Sailor is more than journalistic ghostwriting; I the Supreme is robbed of its punch; Bird of Life, Bird of Death peeks behind Central america’s dictators and dominoes.

toc_entry.title: Treasure From the Vault
toc_entry.subtitle: Jazz
toc_entry.description: New releases of Duke Ellington’s work give us exquisite music from small bands, a dance band having fun, and stereo recording twenty years before its time.

toc_entry.title: Behind the Lines
toc_entry.description: The solution politicians fear.

toc_entry.title: Shopping
toc_entry.description: Sure, a bride needs a groom, but the most important part of any wedding is the dress.

toc_entry.title: Post-Modern Times
toc_entry.description: Houston’s upper crust and underclass mingle at Jo abercrombie’s Wednesday night fights.

toc_entry.title: Downtown
toc_entry.description: Buckle up for your own safety —and save $35.

toc_entry.title: Around the State
toc_entry.description: A selective guide to amusements and events.

toc_entry.title: Reporter
toc_entry.description: The boom has quietly ended in Iraan; fruitivores live longer, says T. C. Fry; a repo man nabs a truck and a sheriff nabs him.

toc_entry.title: Touts
toc_entry.description: These gifts belong to Daddy.

toc_entry.title: The Roar Of the Crowd
toc_entry.description: Toasting tacos; cleaning up the waterfront; replaying the Texaco-Pennzoil case.

toc_entry.title: Puzzle
toc_entry.description: Don’t get your signals crossed.

toc_entry.title: State Secrets
toc_entry.description: Questioning the teachers’ sense —of humor; desperate times breed desperate ideas; a big step toward interstate banking.
